member.name: T:AgEitilt.Common.Dictionary.ObservableDictionary`2
member.summary: Represents a collection of keys and values while notifying listeners when those contents change.
member.remarks:
Retrieving a value by using its key is very fast, close to O(1), because the underlying class is implemented as a hash table.
Each element is a key/value pair stored in a object. When iterated using a foreach loop (For Each in Visual Basic, for each in C++), the enumerated objects are therefore of that type rather than either or .
As long as an object is used as a key in the dictionary, it must not change in any way that affects its hash value. Every key must be unique according to the instance's equality comparer. A key cannot be null, but a value can be if the value type is a reference type.
requires an equality implementation to determine whether keys are equal. You can specify an implementation of the generic interface by using a constructor that accepts a comparer parameter; if you do not specify an implementation, the default generic equality comparer is used. If type implements the generic interface, the default equality comparer uses that implementation.
member.typeparam: The type of keys in the dictionary.
The type of values in the dictionary.

member.name: P:AgEitilt.Common.Dictionary.ObservableDictionary`2.Comparer
member.summary: Gets the that is used to determine equality of keys for the dictionary.
member.remarks: Getting the value of this property is an O(1) operation.
member.value: The generic interface implementation that is used to determine equality of keys for the current and to provide hash values for the keys.

member.name: P:AgEitilt.Common.Dictionary.ObservableDictionary`2.Keys
member.summary: Gets a collection containing the keys in the .
member.remarks:
The order of the keys in the is unspecified, but it is the same order as the associated values in the returned by the property.
The returned is not a static copy; instead, the refers back to the keys in the original . Therefore, changes to the continue to be reflected in the .
Getting the value of this property is an O(1) operation.
member.value: A containing the keys in the .

member.name: P:AgEitilt.Common.Dictionary.ObservableDictionary`2.Values
member.summary: Gets a collection containing the values in the .
member.remarks:
The order of the values in the is unspecified, but it is the same order as the associated values in the returned by the property.
The returned is not a static copy; instead, the refers back to the values in the original . Therefore, changes to the continue to be reflected in the .
Getting the value of this property is an O(1) operation.
member.value: A containing the values in the .

member.param: The value to locate. This can be null for reference types.

member.summary: Returns an enumerator that iterates through the key-value pairs in the dictionary.
member.remarks: This method is an O(1) operation.
member.returns: An enumerator that can be used to iterate through the dictionary.

member.name: T:AgEitilt.Common.Dictionary.IObservableReadOnlyDictionary`2
member.summary: Represents a generic read-only collection of key/value pairs while notifying listeners when those contents change.
member.remarks:
Each element is a key/value pair stored in a object. When iterated using a foreach loop (For Each in Visual Basic, for each in C++), the enumerated objects are therefore of that type rather than either or .
Each pair must have a unique key. Implementations can vary in whether they allow that key to be null. The value can be null and does not have to be unique. The generic allows the contained keys and values to be enumerated, but it does not imply any particular sort order.
member.typeparam: The type of keys in the dictionary.
The type of values in the dictionary.

member.name: T:AgEitilt.Common.Dictionary.ObservableDictionaryBase`2
member.summary: Represents a collection of keys and values while notifying listeners when those contents change, regardless of the underlying .
member.remarks:
Each element is a key/value pair stored in a object. When iterated using a foreach loop (For Each in Visual Basic, for each in C++), the enumerated objects are therefore of that type rather than either or .
Each pair must have a unique key. Implementations can vary in whether they allow that key to be null. The value can be null and does not have to be unique. The generic allows the contained keys and values to be enumerated, but it does not imply any particular sort order.
member.typeparam: The type of keys in the dictionary.
The type of values in the dictionary.

member.name: P:AgEitilt.Common.Dictionary.ObservableDictionaryBase`2.Item(`0)
member.summary: Gets or sets the element with the specified key.
member.remarks:
You can use this property to add new elements by setting the value of a key that does not exist in the dictionary; for example, myDictionary["myNonexistentKey"] = myValue in C# (myCollection("myNonexistentKey") = myValue in Visual Basic). However, if the specified key already exists in the dictionary, setting the value in this manner overwrites the existing element. In contrast, the method does not modify existing elements.
Implementations can vary in whether they allow to be null, but the assigned value can always be as long as is a reference type.
Getting or setting the value of this property approaches an O(1) operation.
member.param: The key of the element to get or set.
member.value: The element with the specified key.
member.exception: is null and the implementation does not support this.
The property is used as an accessor and is not found.
The property is used as a setter and the implementation is read-only.

member.name: P:AgEitilt.Common.Dictionary.ObservableDictionaryBase`2.System#Collections#IDictionary#Item(System.Object)
member.summary: Gets or sets the element with the specified key.
member.remarks:
You can use this property to add new elements by setting the value of a key that does not exist in the dictionary; for example, myDictionary["myNonexistentKey"] = myValue in C# (myCollection("myNonexistentKey") = myValue in Visual Basic). However, if the specified key already exists in the dictionary, setting the value in this manner overwrites the existing element. In contrast, the method does not modify existing elements.
Implementations can vary in whether they allow to be null, but the assigned value can always be as long as is a reference type.
Getting or setting the value of this property approaches an O(1) operation.
member.param: The key of the element to get or set.
member.value: The element with the specified key, or null if the key does not exist.
member.exception: is null and the implementation does not support this.
The property is used as an accessor and is not found.
The property is used as a setter and the implementation is read- only.

member.name: P:AgEitilt.Common.Dictionary.ObservableDictionaryBase`2.IsReadOnly
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether is read-only.
member.remarks: A collection that is read-only does not allow the addition or removal of elements after the collection is created. Note that "read-only" in this context does not indicate whether individual elements of the collection can be modified, since the interface only supports addition, removal, and replacement operations.

member.name: P:AgEitilt.Common.Dictionary.ObservableDictionaryBase`2.System#Collections#IDictionary#IsFixedSize
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether has a fixed size.
member.remarks:
A collection with a fixed size does not allow the addition or removal of elements after the collection is created, but does allow the modification of existing elements.
A collection with a fixed size is simply a collection with a wrapper that prevents adding and removing elements; therefore, if changes are made to the underlying collection, including the addition or removal of elements, the fixed-size collection reflects those changes.

member.name: P:AgEitilt.Common.Dictionary.ObservableDictionaryBase`2.System#Collections#ICollection#IsSynchronized
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether access to is synchronized (thread safe).

member.name: P:AgEitilt.Common.Dictionary.ObservableDictionaryBase`2.System#Collections#ICollection#SyncRoot
member.summary: Gets an object that can be used to synchronize access to the .
member.remarks:
For collections whose underlying store is not publicly available, the expected implementation is to return the current instance. Note that the pointer to the current instance might not be sufficient for collections that wrap other collections; those should return the underlying collection's SyncRoot property.
Most collection classes in the namespace also implement a Synchronized method, which provides a synchronized wrapper around the underlying collection. However, derived classes can provide their own synchronized version of the collection using the SyncRoot property. The synchronizing code must perform operations on the SyncRoot property of the collection, not directly on the collection. This ensures proper operation of collections that are derived from other objects. Specifically, it maintains proper synchronization with other threads that might be simultaneously modifying the collection instance.
Enumerating through a collection is intrinsically not a thread-safe procedure. Even when a collection is synchronized, other threads can still modify the collection, which causes the enumerator to throw an exception. To guarantee thread safety during enumeration, you can either lock the collection during the entire enumeration or catch the exceptions resulting from changes made by other threads.
